Information Extraction from Sample Clinic Letter Dear Dr Clinic notes  Signs and Symptoms moderately fast regular palpitations Many thanks for referring this lady who last year was awoken at night by moderately fast regular palpitations which had a gradual offset. These symptoms have not Medication Ongoing amlodipine 5 mg daily recurred. She is otherwise well although is on treatment simvastatin for hypertension. She stopped smoking 60 years ago calcium supplements and drinks rarely. Recent thyroid function tests have shown a slightly elevated TSH but a normal free. thyroxine. Apart from amlodipine 5 mg daily, she takes Procedure thyroid function tests simvastatin and calcium supplements. Her ECG showed ECG sinus rhythm with a leftward axis. Ambulatory monitoring has shown sinus rhythm with first degree heart block at lower rates and two short salvos of atrial tachycardia of no more than 2 seconds. She was asymptomatic to Diagnosis elevated TSH these. I would pass her tape as within normal limits for normal free thyroxine the patient, and in the absence of ongoing symptoms first degree heart block would not suggest any specific treatment. I will arrange atrial tachycardia for an echocardiogram, however, and will write back further with the results. If she does suffer further Procedure Suggested echocardiogram palpitations, a small dose of bisoprolol such as 1.25 mg daily would be reasonable. With many thanks for your referral. Yours sincerely Medication Suggested bisoprolol 1.25 mg daily cc list Consultant  AlgoAnalytics Pvt. Ltd. | Page 3

Case Study of Industrial Sound Analytics. AlgoAnalytics CONFIDENTIAL AND PROPRIETARY Any use of this material without specific permission AlgoAnalytics is strictly prohibited

Detection of Air Leakage in Industrial Setting  Leakage of compressed air from pneumatic machines and lines is a. common problem in manufacturing industry . Unlike some other gases, air is odourless and colourless  Makes it very hard. to detect leakage of compressed air.  Leakage of compressed air can have significant effect on the performance of the pneumatic equipment. . Not easy to hear for humans due to high background noise in the factory  We use Sound Analytics models to detect leakage of compressed air. in factories . Our models work accurately even in the presence of background noises! . Example: For a MNC client, we detected leakage of air from pneumatic. fixtures in their ultrasonic welding machine!

Classification Results on Air Leakage.  Sound Analvtics was used to detect air leakage at Sharada Industries, Pune .Methodology: Supervised learning used with annotated data collection done at the site. very hard to hear the air leakage sounds. Our proprietary algorithms used to pre-process the data and. mitigate the background noise challenge. .Model Performance: Performance on Air Leakage Detection Location of Air Leakage Accuracy 97.85 Recall 0.99 Precision 0.97 F1 Score 0.99 Highly Accurate Detection of Air Leakage even in Noisy Factories!.
slide_details.Table Summary: Air Leakage Detection achieved 97.85 percent accuracy, 0.99 percent recall

slide_details.Text: D E EP TEK Outlier Detection using Isolation forest www.DeepTek.ai

Brief Introduction to Isolation forests DEEP They are similar to random forest in structure It performs random splits at each node instead of most informative split as used in random forest. Its basic principle is that outliers are very different from the rest of the data in terms of their features and hence Outliers are easy to isolate. easier to isolate By above assumption people have found out that they get classified at a very initial stage in the tree and so the length from the root node to its leaf node is considered to separate them. Inliers are harder to isolate Strictly Confidential Slide: 2
slide_details.Image Summary: The image is a diagram illustrating the relationship between outliers and inliers in a data set. The image is a diagram illustrating the difference in connectivity between outliers and inliers in a data set. It shows a tree-like structure with nodes connected by lines, where the outliers are represented as easier to isolate due to their distinct position in the structure.

slide_details.Text: SVBRDF Acquisition using Deep Learning Conventional BRDF capture setup Background Conventional BRDF capture setups require significant equipment and Environment Light expense. These practices are very time consuming, and rely on skilled artists Lighting This novel lightweight SvBRDF acquisition method can produces state-of-the- art reconstruction quality. The CNN architecture exploits domain knowledge for joint SVBRDF reconstruction and material classification. Material Sample (a) Network Architecture Details: Block-wise study of the architecture C: Classifier- E: Encoder- For predicting material type (reduces size of network) R Consists of convolutional layers that perform down-sampling. DCRF: For removing artefacts, and refining results of the network.. Captured Image D: Decoders (Set of three) - For upsampling Encoder and to get back same sized BRDFs. R: Rendering Layer- Renders BRDFs under known input lighting, producing image with different lighting conditions. Further talks are on...

slide_details.Text: Al Needs Data . Al has shown fantastic results on a wide-range of tasks from object. detection to natural language processing.  Single most important factor that affects performance is the volume of data used for training.. . Deep learning is data hungry..

Data is Often Decentralized . Many valuable datasets are highly decentralized in nature.  Example: Datasets stored with different hospitals form data islands that are isolated from one another.  For conventional machine learning, all data must be moved to a central Iocation before training the models on it.

Challenges in Data Movement : Data exists in different formats and needs to be marshalled into a common format before training . Data sources may be continuously collecting data. Centralization is not a one-time operation.  Communication costs may be prohibitive
Challenges in Maintaining Privacy. Regulations such as GDPR and HIPAA pose hurdles to movement of private data.  Organizations may not be comfortable sharing raw data of their users..

Federated Learning. Round i Round i+1 Federated Learning Selection Configuration Reporting Selection Configuration Repo... enables models to Training learn from private Training Training data without moving Training the data and. Training 3 compromising Training privacy. Device model update is reported back.  Server rejected ones are told to come back later  Server reads model checkpoint from.  Persistent storagee persistent storagee the global model as they arrive X Rejection ("come back later!"). 6) Server writes global model 3 Device or network failure to selected devices checkpoint into persistent storage. Figure: Federated Learning Protocol [1]
slide_details.Image Summary: The image illustrates the Federated Learning Protocol, which is a process used in machine learning where multiple devices (like smartphones or servers) collaborate to train a model without sharing their local data. The image is a diagram representing the Federated Learning Protocol.

slide_details.Text: One Size Does Not Fit All. : Standard federated learning builds one global shared model for all clients. : Some of clients will have more data than others. Data distributions across clients are highly non-llD in practice..  In some cases, a local model using the client's private data may perform significantly better than the federated global model..  Clients that have very little data benefit the most. Clients that have sufficient data to train their own models have no incentive to participate..
Personalization . This paper summarizes techniques used to personalize the global model for each client. and the global model.

1. Adding User Context. . A shared global model can also produce highly personalized predictions if the client's context is featurized and incorporated into the dataset. . Can this be done without adversely affecting privacy?.

2. Transfer Learning . Transfer learning enables deep learning models to utilize the knowledge. gained in solving one problem to solve another related problem.. . Weights of the global model can used as initial weights for further training on local data. . Too much retraining can lead to catastrophic forgetting.

3. Multi-task Learning.  In multi-task learning, multiple related tasks are solved simultaneously allowing the model to exploit commonalities and differences across the tasks by learning them jointly.. : Smith et al. [2] show that multi-task learning is a natural choice to build personalized federated models and develop the MOcHA algorithm for. multi-task learning in the federated setting.. Since it produces one model per task, it is essential that all clients participate in every round..

4. Meta-Learning : Naively optimizing for global accuracy can hurt the model's ability for subsequent. personalization.  Goal is to find a highly adaptable global model that users can subsequently personalize on on local data. . This can be studied within the framework of Model-agnostic meta-learning (MAML) [3]. : Fallah et al. [4] incorporate MAML and propose Per-FedAvg to find a global model that can be easily adapted.

5. Knowledge Distillation . Overfitting poses a significant challenge during personalization, especially for clients whose local dataset is small..  Knowledge distillation [6] involves compressing the knowledge of a large teacher network into a smaller student network by having the student mimic the teacher. . Yu et al. [5] propose that treating the global model as the teacher and the personalized model as the student, the effects of overfitting during. personalization can be mitigated.

6. Base + Personalization Layers. . Arivazhagan et al. [7] propose FedPer, a federated neural network. architecture.  The base layers are trained centrally by Federated Averaging. . The top layers (also called personalization layers) are trained locally with a variant of gradient descent.

Discussion . Most work in FL is focussed on measuring the performance of the global model on aggregated data instead of measuring its performance as seen by individual clients.  Global performance is irrelevant if the global model is expected to be subsequently personalized. : Future work - evaluate the above approaches for personalization and. benchmark results.

Shmatikov, "Salvaging federated learning by local adaptation," arXiv preprint arXiv:2002.04758, 2020. [6] G.Hinton,O.Vinyals,andJ.Dean,Distillingtheknowledgeinaneuralnetwork," arXiv preprint arXiv:1503.02531, 2015.. [7] M. G. Arivazhagan, V. Aggarwal, A. K. Singh, and S. Choudhary, "Federated learning with personalization layers," arXiv preprint. arXiv:1912.00818, 2019.

slide_details.Text: Federated learning  E EF 1 - The clients download the current model from central server and improve it by updating their. model weights based on their local data. The client model parameter updates are aggregated to. generate server model. This model is again downloaded by the clients and the process continues.. 2 - No explicit sharing of raw data in this setup. 3 - Performance drops sharply when local data with clients is non i.i.d.. 4 - Data poisoning attacks on federated learning where malicious users can inject false training data to negatively affect the classification performance of the model have been proposed.. https://arxiv.org/abs/1808.04866 Strictly Confidential Slide: 6

slide_details.Text: Split learning.  E EP 1 - Each client trains the network upto a certain layer known as the cut layer and sends the weights to server. The server then trains the network for rest of the layers. This completes the forward propagation. Server then generates the gradients for the final layer and back-propagates the error until the cut layer. The gradient is then passed over to the client. The rest of the back-propagation is completed by client. This is continued till the network is trained.. 2 - Client-side communication costs are significantly reduced as transmitted data is restricted to first few layers of the SplitNN prior to split. 3 - It requires a relatively larger communication bandwidth when training over a small number of clients 4 - It's has no peeking properties.. Strictly Confidential Slide: 9

Vehicle Data Analytics for Vehicle Health Monitoring and Diagnostics - canonical problem for Industrial IoT ."Al sensors" : Predicting values when no direct sensors are available (e.g. instantaneous fuel consumption). . Real-time prediction of highly dynamic parameters (e.g. fuel trim prediction). ."Al models" .  on highly nonlinear, dynamic data sets with time-delay effect. These characteristics make these models applicable to a wide variety of Industrial IoT problems! AlgoAnalytics Pvt. Ltd Strictly Confidential 11

Instantaneous Fuel Consumption. Instantaneous Fuel Consumption (km/l) varies significantly (from 0 when idling to ~120 when "coasting" with no throttle input) Predicted vs.ActualValues of Instantaneous Fuel Consumption .Varies with throttle input, engine RPM, engine load, vehicle speed, 120 gradient of the road, and many other parameters. Challenges in this case study:. 100 .Highly non-linear time-series data with complex interactions within feature set Primary Data Analysis based on the "physics of the system" showed 80 time delay effects - throttle input in one data instance takes effect at the next instance! Dataset with many different "regimes" - different behaviour in idling, low speed "crawling", city traffic, highway cruising and. "coasting" etc. 40 . We used a Neural Network trained on the ~150,o00 data points and used to predict on a randomly selected 1o0o test points Our predictions has a R? of 99.6 and RMsE of 0.9 (on the scale of 20 km/l variations of 0-120 km/l) .This represents a very accurate prediction system!. A single network that works on all regimes and handled time delay. 40 60 80 100 effects Actural Consumption (km/l) AlgoAnalytics Pvt. Ltd Strictly Confidential. 12

Fuel Trim Prediction .Engine Control unit (EcU) uses Fuel Trim to maintain the stoichiometric air-fuel ratio in a feedback loop .The O2 sensor values are used to estimate how "rich" or "lean" the mixture was, and the fuel trim is the "corrective" step used for next cycle . Short-term fuel trim is the immediate correction to the air fuel ratio : Long-term fuel trim is the longer term correction . Dataset Used: Predic d Values : Train - 1,37,889 observations 63 features : Test - Blind 2000 observations 63 features esults RandomForest-Python Target variable was Short term Fuel trim The ECU computes only 49 discrete values of fuel trims . This this can also be treated as a classification problem, although in theory this is a regression problem : Regression: Using Random Forest, we got R2 = 84.0% . Classification: Using Random Forest Classifier got accuracy of 97.7% and kappa score of 96.6% .Kappa is a more robust statistical measure of the classification performance  49 class classification is a challenge - successfully handled by our models! 200 400 600 800 1000 X0 AlgoAnalytics Pvt. Ltd Strictly Confidential 13

slide_details.Text: Observations on Repeatability Check samples of the data collected 2 weeks ago contains those two sharp peaks, and in the data collected this week, every sample is missing those peaks.. There are visible differences overt time in the amplitude vs time graphs of Surface cut and. bent pole defects.. The pulse based transmitter held manually - this could be one of the factors for the changes. we observe in Amplitude VS Time graphs. Gross defects (Hole Defect and Half cut defect) are almost similar for sets of data collected 2 weeks ago and data collected this week.. Normal poles,for both sets of data, look starkly different in comparison to gross defect poles(half-cut and hole-defect poles) consistently. So, an Al model should also be able to differentiate between normal and gross defect poles. Asquared IoT

Al Approaches Classification > Classification of Normal and Defective Poles classes using Alexnet Architecture classification problems, this is our first choice for initial Al model implementation in the next steps. Object Detection > Find regions of interests in Normal and Defective pole classes and train YOLOv3 model. > The execution time for YOLO is very fast, hence it is perfect for real-time applications.. Even with such a speed, it maintains a good score across various performance metric > If necessary, we will move onto object detection approach with YOLOv3.. We will explore various Al implementations before finalizing one. The final. model would be decided after experimentations by mid-April. Asquared loT

Challenges in input data for AI models. Similarly, for a normal pole audio file. 92000 80500 92000 80500 69000 After chunking to the Frequency (kHz) 69000 Frequency (kHz) 1 second frame 57500 Pulseis-towards the 46000 Pulse left of the frame 23000 11500 50 Time (Seconds)  50 Spectrogram of 1 second chunk 1 second chunks 40 35  (dB) different for normal pole and defective pole.. 30 Pulse AMPLITUDE  If we feed this data into a classification algorithm, it will consider the position of 25 the pulse in the frame as a possible feature to differentiate between defective and normal pole. 20 For instance, in the above graphs, the classifier will call it defective pole if the 15 pulse is in the middle, and it will call normal pole if pulse is on the left of the. frame. 10 Ideally, the Al model should not be consider the position of the pulse to. differentiate between defective and normal poles, hence we have devised a. 5 different approach to segregate into 1 second chunks. Time Asquared loT Amplitude (Seoeprdgh) of 1 second chunk

Overcoming the Challenges. We will use two approaches to overcome the challenges:  Time-window Synchronization: Identifying pulse in the data and synchronizing the time-window using the reference pulse  Time-synchronization using a common device: Using a common device to fire the transmitter as well as recording the ultrasonic signal using USB mic. Asquared loT

Time-window Synchronization. Instead of considering 1 second chunks, we will consider the instance of the pulse and build a frame, starting a fixed milliseconds before the pulse and ending a fixed milliseconds after the pulse, and consider that as a chunk.. This will ensure that the signature of the pulse is in a fixed position (ideally. center) and the model is not trained on the position of the signature but the. differences in the signature for defective and normal poles.. 40 80500 Frame Frame considered considered 35 69000 keeping the  keeping the AMPLITUDE (dB) pulse in the pulse in the 30 57500 centre centre Frequency 46000 25 34500 20 23000 15 11500 10 50 5 Time Time Spectrogkaconsecond chunk Amplitude Vs eogrdph of 1 second chunk Asquared IoT

Time-Synchronization using a Common Device Using Up-Squared Board for Transmission + Reception:. > Use the internal device clock to know the exact time the pulse is transmitted and it can be correlated with the timings of the audio file recorded. This can be used to synchronise the timing information of the pulse and the audio recorded.. However, it will require new data collection. Asquared loT

Plan for next week.  Revise the interim report based on the feedback. Time-Window Synchronization on collected data Train Al models for Defective and Normal pole images  Prepare a report on Initial Al models. Asquared loT

slide_details.Text: Monone Vs Equilips We referred to: http://oi.nttdata.com/en/contest/7th/challenges/pdf/ndiot02 en.pdf . Monone > Monone consists of: Sensors, Edge device, Cloud infrastructure > Use-case: Detecting abnormal sounds > Seems like these would be unsupervised, anomaly detection models at the back-end Equilips > Sensors, Edge device, Cloud is optional > Discriminative learning models at the back-end > Equilips will be expected to perform more accurately if we have failure data Synergy > Outlier detection usually will have lot of false positives. Discriminative learning can be used to reduce false positives > Modern Deep learning methodology using autoencoders, generative methods can be helpful for both Monone and Equilips > Monone can be used in the beginning when we don't have failure data. Summarization Definition: It is the process of shortening a text document with software, in order to create a summary with the major points of the original document. The main idea of summarization is to find a subset of data which contains the "information" of the entire set. Current System: The system picks up sample sentences which tries to cover all points mentioned in the documents. There is no weightage to any of the fields. Summarization in Legal domain: Both extractive and abstractive summarization can be tweaked to summarize the legal documents in a better way. Summary will be comprised of below points: Subject 3. Type of the case 4. Sections, Articles, Laws, Indian penal codes mentioned. 5. Historical Cases Referred.. 6. Brief summary for each of the event happened. 7. Case Status, Result of the case(appleat lost, fined 5oo0 rs, ...etc). Similar Problems solved by us:. 8. News article summarization.. 9. Headline Generation of news articles. 10. Extraction of Judgement from court case Hong Kong Jurisdiction. Best model was giving 80% accuracy. 2

Clustering Definition: Document Clustering is a method for finding structure within a collection of documents, so that similar documents can be grouped into categories. In legal domain, similar case laws can be grouped together, which are having a similar context. This can be helpful for organizing documents and analyzing similar cases. Current system: 1. Considers entire document (case) for clustering irrespective of important fields (domain specific). 2. Works based on word frequency. Doesn't consider semantic meaning.. Improvements for Legal Domain 3.  Weightage can be provided to different fields for better results based on user's requirement such as sections, articles, judges etc E.g : For a query = 'kidnapping' with high weightage to "type of crime" field will result into something like below types clusters: Basic Kidnapping, High Net Worth Individual Kidnapping, Tiger Kidnapping, Express Kidnapping, Virtual Kidnapping, Political Kidnapping, Bride Kidnapping. 4.  Semantic models can be used to consider polysemy words(words with different meaning in different contexts). Same features can be used to create semantic clusters. 5. Legal sections such as laws, sections, acts, indian penal code's description can be used to improvise the clustering results. 3

Important Keywords/Topics Extraction Definition: It is tasked with the automatic identification of terms that best describe the subject of a document. The identified phrases or words can be grouped together based semantic similarity to form the Topics. Current System: 1. Doesn't consider domain knowledge(other documents available in the domain) 2.  Important keywords are extracted based on occurrence based similarity with other words. Extract the words which are most similar to all the other words.. Improvements for Legal domain:. 3. The extracted keywords can be further classified into legal domain specific and case document specific. 4. A ranking algorithm can be applied to rank the keywords and represent them as per their class and rank. 5.This will give a better representation of the case document. A

Named Entity Extraction Definition: Locates and classify named entity mentions in unstructured text into predefined categories such as the person names, organizations, locations, medical codes, time expressions, quantities, monetary values, percentages Current System: 1. Current system is trained to identify below named entities:. PERSON People, including fictional.e ORG Companies, agencies, institutions, etc. GPE Countries, cities, states.. LAW Named documents made into laws. LANGUAGE Any named language. DATE Absolute or relative dates or periods. TIME Times smaller than a day.. MONEY Monetary values, including unit.. 2. Current system is trained on news articles, so it makes some mistakes in identifies entities in legal domain Improvements for Legal Domain: We can improve current NER functionality specific to legal domain. Legal specific types of entities we can include judges, attorneys, companies, jurisdictions, and courts etc. 5

slide_details.Text: Additional feature possibility - Coreference Definition : Coreference resolution is the task of identifying mentions in a text that refer to the same real-world entity. For example, the mentions "Obama", "the president", and "he" could all refer to Barack Obama. Coreference resolution is considered an important aspect of text understanding, and has numerous applications in real world applications. It can be used to find important references in legal documents, simplifying it and improving. its readability. Application : Coreference in legal domain examples :. Sri R.K. Jain, learned senior counsel appeared for Sri Prabhjot Singh. His client was arrested by police. Sri R.K. Jain, learned senior counsel appeared for Sri Prabhjot Singh. Sri R.K. Jain's client was arrested by police.. Triple Extraction We want to extract subject, predicate and object, that we call "triple", in sentence Our target document for demo is contract, but our business target is not only contract, we need to consider more commonly methods that be able to adapt for various documents in Japanese and English.. 1. Implement of state-of-the-art openlE method We want to implement of "Graphene"[Cetto et al. 2018lwith Python, that is an openlE method for complex linguistic structure. We also want to use the method in Japanese, so we expect to use KNp, that is a Japanese on language. 2. Implement and evaluation of another method. We want to evaluate of various triple extraction methods. For example, Bert is powerful methods for improving various NLP algorithm.. We want to implement any way for triple extraction with Bert and validate how performance is improved. Problem Statement To extract subject, predicate, object ( SPO ) triple from contract documents. This problem is to be solved by two methods. It is to be delivered by end of August 2019. Method I: To use Graphene pipeline to extract SPO and to adapt Graphene for different. languages like English, Japanese etc Coreference Transformation Relation Extraction Resolution Method II: Triple extraction with BERT. Modify BERT for contracts Evaluation Improvements documents NTT DaTa  2018 NTT DATA Corporation 3

Approach Graphene is licensed under GNU GPL 3. This means the code needs to be disclosed at some Total source code Graphene modules is more than 13ooo lines of code. To honor the delivery date as end of August 2019, the problem was decided to solve in two phases Phase I 1) Triple extraction using Graphene Java 2) To adapt Graphene for different languages like English, Japanese etc. 3) Triple extraction using BERT. Phase II 1 Re-implement Graphene modules in Python. This proposal is about phase I.  2018 NTT DATA Corporation NTT DaTa

slide_details.Text: OneStop.Al Proposal for Hard Disk. Removal Detection using Video Analysis. AlgoAnalytics CONFIDENTIAL AND PROPRIETARY Any use of this material without specific permission AlgoAnalytics is strictly prohibited

Our Understanding of the Problem  The client takes old computers and refurbishes them or destroys them. Data security of the hard drive is a major issue. The client wants to build a smart ccTV solution in which hard-disk related activity is detected and an alarm is raised. The most critical activity to identify is removal of hard disk from computer and what is done with it

Our Proposed Solution  We will develop a real-time embedded Al system that consists of the following:. A deep learning model that is specifically trained on video inputs from client's work area to detect certain events  This model will use Video as input and will be a video analytics model  This model will be designed to run in real-time. A edge computing hardware system on which the above model will be embedded.  This system will reside in the work area of the client and will operate autonomously without external. intervention  A video camera that will act as the input sensor for the hardware system and the Al model.  A software application (with Ul) that issues alert to the designated person.

Architecture of the Proposed System Edge Device with Embedded AI Deep Learning Local model for Video  Storage Analytics for 7 days embedded on of data Multiple video edge device (24x7) cameras used to monitor the working area Hard-disk removal Identification. (alert can be given in multiple formats as required)

Edge Computing: Compressing the model to run on edge device. DEEP LEARNING TRAINING INFERENCE n3 TRAINING Learn NEW DATASET v.Ca DATA Model Our Expertise: O Optimizing the combination of DL model and Trained Model hardware choices at Performance the edge for real- time DL at edge! Image Credit: https://blogs.nvidia.com/blog/2016/08/22/difference-deep-learning-training-inference-ai/

slide_details.Text: Phases of the Project. We propose the following two phases of development:. Phase 1: Proof of Concept (POc)  Visit to the customer to decide about data collection Data collection and Al model building. Dine tuning the Al model to improve performance as needed Demonstration of the Al model in off-line video analysis. Phase 2: Larger Scale Deployment. Conversion of Al model into stand-alone real-time code. Porting the Al model on edge device.  Deployment into entire work area as per customer requirement.  Enhancement of Al model accuracy by periodic model upgrades.

Steps in Development: Phase 1 (POc)  Step 1: Video Data Collection : 2 team members from AlgoAnalytics to visit Japan site. clock) .The data should include all type of hardware included (laptops/ PCs/ Servers).  Labeling and annotation on the video data . We need one week of video data to start Al model training. : Step 2: Model Building and Fine-Tuning .We build the deep learning model on the first set of data .  2 member AlgoAnalytics team will visit the customer site to test this model on new data . Fine-tuning of the model to improve the accuracy on the test data. :  Demonstration of the model output to the customer as deliverable of POC.

Steps in Development: Phase 2. Step 3: Choosing the right hardware and embedding the AI mode.  Step 4: Converting the Al model into stand-alone real-time model and porting on the edge device Step 5: Expanding the area of coverage. Step 6: Narrowing down the definitions of activities reported. Step 7: Fine-tuning the models as per narrowed down definitions Step 6: User Acceptance Test (uAT) and Deployment.

Timeline for Phase 1 (POc) Phase 1 (POc) will take 4 months of time (Estimate as of now; may change after detailed study of the specific POC selected) Month 1 Month 2 Month 3 Month 4 Data Collection & Annotation Initial Model Building Testing with New Data Fine-tuning Model Report & Deliverables

Grammar : koala NOM leaf ACC slowly MAN eat PAST Topic Extraction, Named Entity Recognition, Text. English : "The koala slowly ate a leaf". Classification, Text Clustering, Text SImilarity, Paragraph Compre etc. English *A few fields stand out as particularly important to Japanese:. Japanese Chunking and Machine Translation Segmentation: part-of-speech tagging, lemmatization. Location entity extraction etc.. A Machine Translation: Machine translation research has always been a big topic in Japanese NLP. Two important steps of this are Syntactic transfer and Semantic transfer. Verb Verb Subject Object Syntactic transfer contains - part of speech tagging, Entity extraction, coreference resolution etc.. slide_details.Text: Auto insurance fraud detection.  Auto insurance fraud costs genuine consumers, companies and the economy at large. Combating fraud with a well-thought-out analytics plan helps insurance companies conduct their business efficiently, increase customer satisfaction and enhance their overall brand image..  Using deep learning we are able to improve the rate of genuine claims and significantly reduce costs associated with fraud claims investigation.. The trained model was able to correctly predict ~65 % of the genuine claims, and ~81% of the frauds.. Japanese Chunking and Machine Translation Segmentation: part-of-speech tagging, lemmatization. Location entity extraction etc.. A Machine Translation: Machine translation research has always been a big topic in Japanese NLP. Two important steps of this are Syntactic transfer and Semantic transfer. Challenges Japanese language: verb-final language Challenges in Japanese NLP Japanese : 0000 0000030  Current research topics on Japanese natural language processing: Information Extraction, Information Retrieval. Grammar : koala NOM leaf ACC slowly MAN eat PAST Topic Extraction, Named Entity Recognition, Text. English : "The koala slowly ate a leaf". Classification, Text Clustering, Text SImilarity, Paragraph Compre etc. English *A few fields stand out as particularly important to Japanese:. Japanese Chunking and Machine Translation Segmentation: part-of-speech tagging, lemmatization. Location entity extraction etc.. A Machine Translation: Machine translation research has always been a big topic in Japanese NLP. Two important steps of this are Syntactic transfer and Semantic transfer. Verb Verb Subject Object Syntactic transfer contains - part of speech tagging, Entity extraction, coreference resolution etc.. Semantic transfer includes - Word embeddings, text Origin Co-participant Destination similarity, text classification etc. Destination Co-participant O 2018 NTT DATA Corporation 23 NTT DaTa

slide_details.Text: Automatic Reply to Customer Grievance using AI Customer service has been automating processes for decades.. Currently, customer services send an automated email response, which are then served by human operators. Now Customer won't have to wait as Al can read emails, know the sender, understand the context and send appropriate replies to common customer queries/grievances Examples Hello Customer Care Hi When is my premium due? At what age should I purchase life insurance policy ? Hi Vinit,. What is your insurance ID?  Hi Tejal It is 123412542151. You should buy Life Insurance as soon as possible, and  definitely as soon as you start earning. Buy when you are. young so that your family's future is secure and you get.  plans, buying early also gives a greater chance for your. wealth to grow... Hi Vinit Your due date is 31 May 2019. Amount is Rs. 50,000 AL 23

Sentiment Analysis of customer reviews. food positive We visited here during our recent trip to Sydney and overall we were very impressed. We decided to make a reservation online,which was quick and easy with instant confirmation.It was nice to be able to view the table layout and select our own online. The location is reservations positive spectacular with stunning views of the harbour and Opera House.It truly was amazing.Despite this,however, the restaurant was only about 25% full and so the atmosphere was a bit flat. Perhaps this was to our benefit as we received top class service from our waiter, Brandon, who was not only friendly and funny but extremely knowledgeable when it came to food and wine value positive pairings.Speaking of wine, the list was extensive-we loved it- and it took us what seemed like an hour to eventually decide on a loca/ Shiraz.Now on to the most important aspect, the food. Our seafood starters were delicious, as were out fillet steak mains. The one and only real desserts negative disappointment was the dessert which was served with no real imagination and looked like it had been purchased yesterday at the local grocery store.All in all, my favourite Sydney restaurant so far. So many positives and really good value too.Highly recommend location positive otripadvisor yelp amazon facebook. twitter ambience neutral Create Document Analyze Aspect-.. staff positive drinks positive AL 24

slide_details.Text: Our Proposed Solution  We will develop a real-time embedded Al system that consists of the following:. A deep learning model that is specifically trained on video inputs from client's work area to detect certain events  This model will use Video as input and will be a video analytics model  This model will be designed to run in real-time. A edge computing hardware system on which the above model will be embedded.  This system will reside in the work area of the client and will operate autonomously without external. intervention  A video camera that will act as the input sensor for the hardware system and the Al model.  A software application (with Ul) that issues alert to the designated person.

Architecture of the Proposed System Edge Device with Embedded AI Deep Learning Local model for Video  Storage Analytics for 7 days embedded on of data Multiple video edge device (24x7) cameras used to monitor the working area Hard-disk theft Identification. (alert can be given in multiple formats as required)

Phases of the Project. We propose the following two phases of development: Phase 1: Proof of Concept (Poc) - proof of concept is a working system with all major features but which works in limited environment. Visit to the customer to decide about data collection Data collection and Al model building. Fine tuning the Al model to improve performance as needed Demonstration of the Al model in off-line video analysis Conversion of Al model into stand-alone real-time code  Porting the Al model on edge device. Phase 2: Larger Scale Deployment. Deployment into entire work area as per customer requirement .Defining specific activity that has to be detected Enhancement of Al model accuracy by periodic model upgrades

Steps in Development: Phase 1 (POc) .Step 1: Video Data Collection :2 team members from AlgoAnalytics to visit Japan site : Our current suggestion is collection of data from one workstation in 4 angles (4 cameras with sync clock) The data should include all type of hardware included (laptops/ PCs/ Servers) Data should include people removing hard disks from devices and putting it in their pockets, this can be "acting". This will be training data . One week of normal video data collection for testing data Labeling and annotation on the video data :We need one week of video data to start Al model training : Step 2: Model Building and Fine-Tuning .We build the deep learning model on the first set of data 2 member AlgoAnalytics team will visit the customer site to test this model on new data .Fine-tuning of the model to improve the accuracy on the test data from that one workstation . Demonstration of the model output to the customer as deliverable of POC .Step 3: Porting the Model on Edge Device . Choosing the right hardware and embedding the Al model Converting the Al model into stand-alone real-time model and porting on the edge device

Steps in Development: Phase 2. Step 5: Expanding the area of coverage Step 6: Narrowing down the definitions of activities reported . Step 7: Fine-tuning the models as per narrowed down definitions. Step 6: User Acceptance Test (uAT) and Deployment.

slide_details.Text: Deliverables at the End of Phase 1 (Poc).  The deliverables the end of Phase 1 (poc) will include:. An offline model that identifies hard-disk theft events from video inputs Demonstration of the model, and a detailed performance report Documentation on how to use the model. The deliverables will be in English. Detailed Proposal for Phase 2  Phase 2 proposal will be submitted at the end of Phase 1.

Limitations of Mode This model will be limited for one workstation only in phase 1. It will generate alert only when the action is captured on any of the cameras for this particular workstation only If the action happens outside the camera monitored area of this workstation, the system will not work The model will be tuned to capture any sensitive activity that looks like theft. It might generate more false positives.

Cost and Time Estimation for Phase 1 The cost for this phase will be $150,o00 excluding travel costs and cost of hardware 2 of our team members will travel to the client site for one week at the beginning of the project and one week towards the end of phase 1 (This will be at actuals - travel + stay + food) We will need help from one technical person + one bi-lingual person/project manager from Japan side. 15

slide_details.Text: Bone Abnormality Detection. Problem Statement: Determine whether a bone structure is normal or abnormal by using X-ray image. Dataset :  MuRA (Musculoskeletal Radiographs) is a dataset made available by Stanford ML group consisting of 14,863 studies from 12,173 patients, with a total of 40,561 multi-view radiographic images. Each belongs to one of seven standard upper extremity radiographic study types: elbow, finger, forearm, hand, humerus, shoulder and wrist. Network Architecture :  Versions of "DenseNet" architecture such as DenseNet121, DenseNet169 were finetuned on the dataset Separate models was built for each of the seven study types. After starting in 2016, we have executed 100+ projects with marquee clients. We have a strong team of 50+ data scientists on our premises. Ltd. | Page  4

slide_details.Text: Approach in Detail: Object Detection Using Deep Learning. 2. Faster RCNN: i. R-cNN and Fast R-cNN uses selective search to find out the region proposals. Selective search is a slow and time-consuming process affecting the performance of the network. network is used to predict the region proposals. iii. The predicted region proposals are then reshaped using a Rol pooling layer which is then used to classify the. image within the proposed region and predict the offset values for the bounding boxes.. R-CNN Test-Time Speed FastR-CNN Faster R-CNN  AlgoAnalytics Pvt. Ltd. | Page 12

Approach in Detail: Object Detection Using Deep Learning 3. YoloV3: i. Yolo didn't use the region based approach as previous algorithm. ii. It take an image and split it into an SxS grid, within each of the grid we take m bounding boxes. iii. For each of the bounding box, the network outputs a class probability and offset values for the bounding box.. The bounding boxes having the class probability above a threshold value is selected and used to locate the object within the image. iv. We can use YoloV3 algorithm for real time object detection..  AlgoAnalytics Pvt. Ltd. | Page 13
slide_details.Image Summary: The image appears to be a representation of a process in computer vision, specifically object detection. It shows an initial image with a grid superimposed on it, and then a series of bounding boxes with varying levels of confidence surrounding objects within the image. The final step involves detecting the objects, as indicated by the colored bounding boxes. The image depicts a process in object detection using bounding boxes and confidence levels. It starts with an initial grid on the input image, which is then refined through bounding boxes and confidence levels to arrive at final detections.

slide_details.Text: Approach in Detail: Image Segmentation Using Deep Learning Mask RCNN Object detection returns bounding box over the object, hence there is a possibility of the algorithm assigning the non-corrosion part as corrosion. In segmentation, the alogirhtm provides arbitrary boundary taking care of this issue.. ii. In the example Green box shows the Object detection bounding box and Blue boundary shows the Image Segmentation output.. iii. Mask R-cNN is an extension over Faster R-cNN, adding one more branch for predicting an object mask in parallel. iv. Backbone model: a standard convolutional neural network that serves as a feature extractor. For example, it will turn a1024x1024x3 image into a 32x32x2048 feature map that serves as input for the next layers.. V. Region Proposal Network (RpN): Using regions defined with as many as 200K anchor boxes, the RPN scans each region and predicts whether or not an object is present. vi. Region of Interest Classification and Bounding Box: In this step the algorithm takes the regions of interest proposed by the RPN as inputs and outputs a classification (softmax) and a bounding box (regressor). vil.  Segmentation Masks: In the final step, the algorithm the positive ROl regions are taken in as inputs and 28x28 pixel masks with float values are generated as outputs for the objects. During inference, these masks are scaled up..  AlgoAnalytics Pvt. Ltd. | Page 14

In some other machines, there is so much overlap between the two classes, that the parameter 'kappa' goes down even further (below 0.5). Asquared IoT

Some Methods To Improve Performance  We moved from a three-class model approach to a two-tier two-class model approach, which seems to give a considerably better performance for classes saw-off and saw-on. Classes saw-on-cut-off vs saw-on-cut-on still needs to be worked on as the accuracies are not meeting the target.  Class 1 (saw-on-cut-off) vs class 2 (saw-on-cut-on) is still a challenge due to the. minority class problem (class 1 and class 2 are highly imbalanced). As well as. the distinction between these classes is not as crisp as that of saw-off vs saw- on, and there is an overlap.  Earlier, there was less variation in the data available, which made the model fail in certain test-cases. We improved the variation in one of the machines, M7, by using Data Augmentation. This led to 20% increase in performance. However, this technique may or may not work for the other machines. That is yet to be seen. Asquared loT

Some Methods To Improve Performance . Data Augmentation uses : Intensity variation, Pitch variation, Time-shift and Adding White-noise. We are further looking into GANs for generation of data. . We are looking into deeper neural networks. Asquared loT

What is Artificial Intelligence (AI)? .The theory and development of computer systems. able to perform tasks normally requiring human. intelligence  Such as visual perception, speech recognition, decision. making, and translation between languages etc.. A branch of Computer Science dealing with simulation of intelligent behaviour in computers .Machine Learning is a type of Artificial Intelligence. that provides computers with the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed Asquared loT

Early History of AI.  1950: English Mathematician Alan Turing wrote a benchmark paper that asked the question "Can Machines Think?"  Proposed "Turing Test" - used even today!  1956: American scientist John McCarthy first coined the term "Artificial. Intelligence" and held the first academic conference on this topic at Dartmouth Asquared IoT

The Mid-History of AI  1956- 1974 "The Golder Years": Several innovative applications to games, word problems, Proving theorems, and natural. language : 1974: Backpropagation Algorithm proposed for neural nets - used even today is various forms  1997: IBM Deep Blue defeats Chess World. Champion Garry Kasparov  1998: Convolutional Neural Networks for. handwriting recognition Asquared IoT

The Modern History of Al. (2000-)  2006: Enterprise use of Al with Facebook etc start using Al : 2011: Google Brain Project & Rise of "Deep 621,600 Learning" (DL) that changed the world of AI : 2011: IBM Watson won Jeopardy against human champions 2012: Alexet Wins "ImageNet" & Rise of the modern DL for image recognition. AIM.GENET  2012 onward: Explosion of Al and DL research and applications Asquared IoT

Deep Learning - the most popular Al model today!. Note Jan 1, 2004 Dct 1, 2008 u1, 2013 Apr 1, 2018 100 Google Search popularity for "Deep Leaning" from 2004 till present. 50 Note n 1, 2004 Oct 1, 2008 JuI 1, 2013 Apr 1, 2018 Asquared loT

3 Key Catalysts in Recent Rise of AI Abundance of compute power Abundance of data 110010010 10000010000 n0001 Simple Neural Networke Deep Learning Neural Network Advances in algorithmic research 0Input Layer OHidden Layer O Output Layer Asquared IoT

Weak AI and Strong AI  Weak AI: An Al program that can meet or exceed human performance. in a narrow, specific field - Already a reality!.  Pattern-based AI: Computer solved problems by detecting useful patterns in the data  Most Al applications today belong to this class  E.g. IBM Deep Blue, Medical image analysis, autonomous driving etc. Strong Al or "Artificial General Intelligence": Al models generalizing the knowledge to any field, matching or exceeding human performance -. We do NOT have this today! X  Programs capable of abstract reasoning and thinking. Asquared IoT

Introduction to Deep Learning (DL) . Part of machine learning field which deals with learning representations of unstructured data  Very effective at learning patterns from unstructured data  Widely used for image and video analysis  Specific type of neural network architectures designed to understand the right representation of the data to solve the task in hand  Utilizes learning algorithms that derive meaning out of data by using a hierarchy of multiple layers that mimic the neural networks of our brain.  If you provide the system tons of information, it begins to understand it and respond in useful ways. Asquared loT

slide_details.Text: However, There Are Limitations. . Data: Al needs lot of data, and good quality of data.  In most cases the data needs to he tagged or labelled, often manually  Bias: Data often has a bias, and the model learns this bias  No one-size-fits-all solution: Requires customization for each problem  Stochastic, not deterministic. . Can't really think: Al can only do what it is programmed to do Lack of interpretability: Al can't "explain" its results Asquared loT

slide_details.Text: 1) Harnesses the powerful representative power of CNNs to create high level representations 3) A memory network combines learning strategies from the machine learning literature with a memory. component that can be read and written to. The model is trained to learn how to operate effectively with. the memory component.
Learning Memory-guided Normality for AD Input I Memory Module M items K queries Update Output i

Memory Networks The high-level view of a memory network is as follows: An input feature map I, which converts the incoming input to the internal feature representation A generalization component G which updates old memories given the new input. "We call this generalization as there is an opportunity for the network to compress and generalize its memories at this stage for some intended future use." An output feature map O, which produces a new output in the feature representation space given the new input and the current memory state A response component R which converts the output into the response format desired - for example, a textual response or an action.. A Memor I(x) I(x) O(Ix), G andano x qndu R Memory

slide_details.Text: Introduction Deep Learning is finding its feet in different fields. However, due to latency issues, we cannot harness the full power.. Thus, we try to deploy models on-site using edge devices.. lesser latency.

Hardware Options  Intel NCS2 - Frameworks supported - TensorFlow, Caffe NVidia Jetson - Frameworks supported - TensorFlow, Caffe. ARM Ethos N-77 - Frameworks supported - TensorFlow, TensorFlow Lite, Caffe2, PyTorch, MXNet

Deployment Techniques Due to the limited memory and computation resources of edge devices, training large amounts of data on the devices is not feasible most of the times. The deep learning models are trained in powerful on In the future, distributed techniques could be used where IoT devices share all the data. However, this is limited by network restrictions and can be explored post 5G

slide_details.Text: NVidia DeepStream SDK(contd.) DeepStream SDK offers a complete streaming analytics toolkit for video and image understanding. DeepStream is used heavily for IVA(Intelligent Video Analytics). DeepStream offers pre-trained models on Transfer Learning Toolkit(TLT).. With DeepStream SDK you can apply AI to streaming video and can simultaneously optimize video decode/encode, image scaling and conversion and edge-to-cloud connectivity for complete end-to-end performance optimization.

NVidia TensorRT SDK for high performance Deep Learning inference.. Built on CUDA and harnesses the power of CUDA-X Can be used to quantize an calibrate products for lower precision without a loss in accuracy. Accepts trained models from various Deep Learning Frameworks..

NVidia TensorRT features  Weight and activation precision calibration - INT8 Calibration Layer and Tension fusion - Optimizes use of GPU memory Kernel auto-tuning - Select best algorithms depending on platform Multi-Stream Execution - Scalable design allows multiple input streams

NVidia Jetpack SDK  NVidia JetPack supports all Jetson modules and developer kits. Used to deploy and reproduce environments on Jetson devices Key features are: OS TensorRT CudNN Cuda Multimedia API Developer tools JetPack also supports DeepStream SDK

References  https://developer.nvidia.com/tensorrt  https://developer.nvidia.com/embedded/jetpack https://developer.nvidia.com/deepstream-sdk https:/www.therobotreport.com/why-and-how-to-run-machine-learning-algorithms-on-edge-devices/

Prob|em Context  Hospital orders medical supplies from various vendors. One item can be sourced from multiple vendors Item has a description, which is like concatenated word tokens about various attributes of the item. Later, when the hospital wants to search/compare/match these items, it requires the item attributes in structured pattern.

Solution and reference The item description strings can be matched when represented as vector assuming the attributes have meaningful representation, irrespective of their position in the string. This approach is popularly used in retail or ecommerce operations. It is known as product matching.. Item description is mapped in attributes [map phase], combine or arrange attributes [merge or structure phase]. This kind of approach is more closer to address delineation problem popularly used in logistic. industries.

Choice of problem reference . Address delineation problem Input Addresses Output Standardized Addresses ADDRESS HouseNumPreDir PreTypeStreetNameSufTypeSufDir 1171 PIEDMONT AVENUE NE 1171 PIEDMONT AVE NE 1670 WEST PEACHTREE ST NE 1670 ST NE W PEACHTREE 400 FIRST ST NV 400 1ST ST NV 241 16TH STREET NWV 241 16TH ST NV 120 MEMORIAL DRIVE SE 120 MEMORIAL DR SE 360 AVENUE B NORTH 360 AVE B N 151 HIGHWAY 13 151 HVY 13 200 ST LAUREN BOULVARD 200 SAINT LAURENBLVD

slide_details.Text: Problem Technical Frame Given a string which describes medical supply item in plain word concatenation form (and not a well formed english sentence), categorize the string tokens in various categories  This can be seen as token classification / entity recognition / keyphrase extraction problem. Retractor Lid Desmarres, W:14mm, L:130mm -> Merge (based on domain or expert rule -> Desmarres Retractor Tool : "Retractor" , Tool subtype 1 : "Lid", Tool subtype 2 : "Desmarres", Measurements : W 14mm, L 130mm

Outline of approaches 1. Data generation by randomization and then token classification using RNN varieties. Ref : a.https://github.com/jasonrig/address-net b.https://towardsdatascience.com/addressnet-how-to-build-a-robust-street-address-parser-using-a-recurrent-neural-network-518d97b9aebd 2. Combine database and taxonomy and HMM like model.. a.https://www.cse.iitb.ac.in/~sunita/papers/sigmod01.pdf 3. Examine relation between clean records and unstructured text. Does not require label data. a.http://www.mathcs.emory.edu/~eugene/papers/kdd04segmentation.pdf 4. CRF based approach with features and generated data. a. https://www.analyticsvidhya.com/blog/2018/08/nlp-guide-conditional-random-fields-text-classification/ b.  https://medium.com/finastra-fintechs-devs/a-practical-proof-of-concept-using-natural-language-processing-to-parse-unstructured-text-62fa94 852708

Possible technical implementation. 1. Character based RNN : https://github.com/jasonrig/address-net 2. Flair : https://medium.com/thecyphy/training-custom-ner-model-using-flair-df1f9ea9c762 (Lets you choose CRF / bi LSTM) 3. Data generation : https://github.com/joke2k/faker 4. Base embedding may help : https://allenai.github.io/scispacy/. 5. In merge phase : https://towardsdatascience.com/keyword-extraction-with-bert-724efca412ea 6. Entity Ruler : utilize dictionary using. a.https://spacy.io/usage/rule-based-matching#entityruler b.https://github.com/mpuig/spacy-lookup 7. Wiki query : https://towardsdatascience.com/wikipedia-api-for-python-241cfae09f1c

Task List. Decoding Target schema : List all the possible output attributes. Have their loose definitions. Example : Tool name, Anatomy, Tool Brand, Tool type [Use doctors help for correct attribute names] 2. For major well known entity types find dictionaries on net or prepare dictionaries from data. Examples I found are. a.https://drive.google.com/file/d/1odSDvVon4E1hgSos9ztw8AIQ-RYpUEfq/view?usp=sharing 3. Also use wiki API for validation and dictionary creation. This is finite domain for NER. Hence more you build knowledge, more the accuracy.. 4. Use faker for data creation. 5. List features for each entity type. There can be many. This usually helps in building post processing rules or secondary classic ML model.. a. Position offset b. Name C.  Dictionary entry  d.Alphanumeric character 6. Quick Approach : Approach 1 and 4 (Implementation available) 7. Deeper Approach : Approach 2 and 3 (Need understanding and implementation of paper).

Accuracy and Time estimation  From my survey and experience, this problem can be solved with 9o%+ accuracy for important and. frequently occurring attributes. With dictionaries, data cleaning and some post processing tricks, I think this problem can be solved near 95%+ accuracy.  For POC, we should try approach 1 and 4. And I estimate it could be 2 person weeks effort..

The overall architecture of the proposed network. The backbone has 25 convolution layers and is divided into four parts: tiny part, small part, medium part and large part. Along the backbone, there are eight loss branches which are in charge of detecting faces with  different scales. The entire backbone only consists of conv 3 3, conv 1 1, ReLU and residual connection.. LFFD Version 1: 0 Contains 8 output branches, each branch responsible for detecting faces of particular size Can detect faces of size between 10 pixels to 560 pixels. O 0 Earlier branches -> Tiny faces Deeper branches -> Large faces Therefore, there is possibility to optimize model by removing last few branches. While detection, we will need to resize input image to a smaller size. May result in faster inference time..

INTRODUCTION / OBJECTIVES DEEP Healthcare data is almost always distributed and comes from various data sources (multi-hospitals, multi-modal etc). Most of these healthcare centres are rightfully protective of the data and do not allow free sharing of the data across networks and national boundaries.. The power of deep learning is best utilized when the neural network is trained using a large amount of data from various sources, demographics and cohorts.. One of the ways of handling this situation while still making use of the knowledge from various sources is to use. distributed data learning. Federated learning by Google and Split learning by MIT media lab are two of the cutting-edge ways of solving. the problem. Strictly Confidential Slide: 2

slide_details.Text: FEDERATED LEARNING DEEP 1. A generic (shared) model is trained server-side. 2. A number of clients are selected for training on top of the generic Federated learning model. combined updated model data device model 3.  The selected clients download the model.  The generic model is trained on the devices, leveraging the user's private data. 5. A summary of the changes made to the model (i.e. weights of the trained neural network) is sent to the server. nitial model  The server aggregates the updates from all devices to improve the shared model using federated averaging algorithm. Google 7. The process of sending the generic model to mobile devices and updating them according to the received summary of updates is repeated. Federated learning combined model data device (another) initial model Google Strictly Confidential Slide: 4

SPLIT LEARNING DEEP Each client takes inputs and does a forward pass up to a certain layer(cut layer).  The clients then send these activations to the server. The server does a forward pass for rest of the layers, which completes the Back +Prop forward propagation. Smashed Data Server then generates the gradients for the final layer and back Client propagates the error up to the cut layer. Smasher - The gradients are then passed over to the clients where rest of the back- Client1 Client2 Client3.. propagation is completed. Figure 1: Vanilla split learning setup showing This is continued till the network is trained. distribution of layers Figure 2: Split learning setup with across client and server. multiple clients and a server with dot- ted green line showing the split be- tween the client's share of layers and the server's share of layers. Activa tions from only the split layer (last layer of client) are shared during for ward propagation and gradients from only first layer of server are shared with client during backpropagation. Strictly Confidential Slide: 5

slide_details.Text: Technique Convolutional AutoEncoder architecture is used by training it on image data from normal class. It learns to reconstruct back the original image after compressing it to a lower dimension. Since information is passed through a small bottleneck, the model only learns to. reconstruct normal images and any image which is not from normal distribution is not reconstructed properly.. VGG-16 pre-trained on the huge dataset of ImageNet is used to encode the information into smaller dimension.. The objective function minimized during training is the pixel-wise MsE between input and reconstructed image. Image reconstruction is improved greatly by adding a VGG perceptual Ioss along with MSE during training : along with MSE, the distance between embeddings from a VGG ImageNet pre-trained model of input and reconstructed image is minimized, i.e. the model is learns to. After training, the anomaly score for a particular image is calculated by measuring similarity between input and reconstructed image. The metric here used is ssim index. Low similarity or low SSIM index indicates high abnormality in the image..
